message: Roll Tide and Happy New Year! Wishing you and yours a happy, healthy, and prosperous 2017.
Excited to kick off 2017 with the start of the 115th Congress! I'm confident that we'll begin to accomplish great things for Americans with a unified Republican government.

Happy to congratulate my colleague Speaker Paul Ryan on his reelection as Speaker of the House. I'm eager to continue working with him to advance conservatism and serve the American people.

I was honored to be sworn-in to the 115th Congress today. It's truly a privilege to represent the people of Alabama's 2nd Congressional District. With every vote I cast and every action I take in Congress, I have one simple principle: Alabama always comes first. Whether it is supporting Maxwell Air Force Base and Fort Rucker, maintaining our progress in improving veterans healthcare, or advancing smart agriculture policy, I will continue to prioritize issues affecting my state and district.    There is so much work to be done to put this country back on the right track. I‚Äôm eager to work with a unified Republican government to deliver results that make a positive difference for the American people. We have a unique opportunity to use conservative ideals to put our country on a more responsible, sustainable path. I‚Äôm excited to be a part of this historic moment and ready to get to work.

Busy first week of the 115th Congress as we tackle veterans legislation, push transparency for taxpayers, make strides toward reining in some costly regulations, and more. Today's vote schedule below.

No time wasted: the first bills passed by the House in the 115th Congress are aimed at bringing more accountability to the VA.   Yesterday, the House unanimously passed the Ensuring VA Accountability Act, which ends the VA practice of scrubbing black marks off employee files. While the vast majority of VA employees care deeply about our veterans and work very hard to care for them, it‚Äôs no secret that some bad actors have not been held accountable for poor performance.   This piece of legislation is a step in the right direction, and I was proud to support it. I'm encouraged that veterans are a top priority in the 115th Congress, and we demonstrated our commitment to them by addressing some key issues on day one.

Set your DVR! This Sunday at 5:30p.m., Alabama Public Television will air its new eduational documentary project "Inside Congress: Alabama to DC."   About a year ago, Roy Clem, the Exectuive Director of Alabama Public Television, reached out to my office about documenting the daily work life of a Unites States Congressman. I thought it was an interesting idea, and so we opened up our office to filmmaker Mark Fastoso and his talented team. Mark is known for his most recent work, ‚ÄúJEREMIAH,‚Äù the documentary profile of former U.S. Senator Jeremiah Denton who famously blinked T-O-R-T-U-R-E as a prisoner of war in Vietnam. He won four Emmy Awards and the Edward R. Murrow Award for the film.   With the start of a new Congress and new presidential administration about to take office, there is a lot of interest in government right now. It‚Äôs really the perfect time to offer this inside look into what happens in Congress.   Having a camera crew follow your every move (even in the car and to the grocery store) is an interesting experience to say the least. But so much goes on in our day-to-day that most never get to see, so I hope this film offers students and adults alike a glimpse into our sometimes chaotic world. I'm also pleased that the film captures the hard work of my staff, who do so much to help constituents in need.   Enjoy this short preview and be sure to tune in to catch the full film on Alabama Public Televsion at 5:30 this Sunday.

Head's up: tomorrow the House will take up an important measure striking the "last minute" Obama Administration rule attempting to force states to direct their Title X dollars to abortion clinics.   It was called by some President Obama's "parting gift to Planned Parenthood": an eleventh hour HHS regulation that threatens to take away Title X public health funding from any state that chooses to direct those dollars to clinics that do not perform abortions. You read that correctly. If a state, like Alabama, rightfully chooses to make sure its pass-through public health dollars are directed toward health clinics that do not perform abortions, it would be in violation of this rule and liable to get its federal funds taken away.   I've long been outspoken about the need to stop taxpayer funding from going to prop up abortion clinics. Our legislation to do that was vetoed by President Obama. That didn't stop some states from taking action to make sure the Title X funds they receive go to true health centers and not abortion clinics - which they have every right to do. But, thanks to the abortion industry's fierce allies in the Obama Administration, this regulation was put in place to quash those state efforts.   Tomorrow, the House will consider a bill to utilize our authority under the Congressional Review Act to officially "disapprove" this rule and strike it altogether. I proudly support this measure, and look forward to joining the debate. I'll be making two important points: first, the federal government has no business telling states they can't enact reasonable rules on how they spend federal health dollars. Second, there is no place in the budget of the United States for the funding of abortion clinics, and this is just one of many steps that need to be taken to stop the pipeline of federal funding for nation's largest abortion business.

For Washington to attempt to coerce states into spending their federal dollars in certain ways is bad enough, but the fact that the Obama Administration circumvented Congress with this last-minute rule is outrageous.

Tomorrow the House will take up three bills from the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs:  1. The VA Accountability First Act of 2017 provides the VA Secretary with increased authority to remove, demote, or suspend any VA employee for poor performance or misconduct. It also includes important safeguards for whistleblowers.   2. Specifically, the bill would ensure that only a judge or magistrate ‚Äì not a VA bureaucrat ‚Äì has the authority to rule that a beneficiary is a danger to themselves or others.   3. Today I spoke out in favor of bringing more accountability to the VA. Two & a half years ago, in the wake of the veterans wait list scandal, Congress rightfully passed legislation giving the VA Secretary greater authority to fire senior managers responsible for those failures. You may remember that the director of our own scandal-ridden Central Alabama VA became the first to be fired under that new law. Mr. Speaker, I‚Äôve said for years that the canary in the coalmine for our success in Afghanistan going forward is the preservation of the gains made by women and girls. Having observed the treatment of women and girls over many years now, I can tell you that the progress today is as fragile as ever.   There is good news. Proud the House took action Thursday to support the nation‚Äôs law enforcement by passing the Thin Blue Line Act. It is time to send a clear message: If you kill a law enforcement officer, you will be brought to justice and punished to the full extent of the law.   Law enforcement offers need more than equipment and funding ‚Äì they need our support. They need our support because they are under attack.  The last few years have seen a disturbing uptick in the instances of police being targeted by violent criminals just because they are wearing a badge. According to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, at least 64 police officers were shot and killed in the line of duty last year, 21 one of which were ambush-style killings. Attacks in Dallas, Baton Rouge, Chicago, and other places were chilling reminders of the dangers these brave individuals face when they go to work.   Under current federal law, killing a federal law enforcement officer is an aggravating factor when considering a death sentence for the offender ‚Äì just as it should be.    However, that same deterrent and protection is not extended to state or local police officers, firefighters, or first responders. The Thin Blue Line Act would change this by making the murder of local law enforcement an aggravating factor when considering a death sentence.

Congress must always ensure our law enforcement agencies have the proper tools and resources to get the job done. I‚Äôm honored to play a role in this important work through my service on the Judiciary Committee and the Appropriations Subcommittee for Commerce, Justice and Science.   Marking National Police Week, the House passed a slate of bills aimed to offer greater protections for law enforcement officers and properly honor heroes. Here's a list of the legislation:  - H.R. 115, the Thin Blue Line Act; amends the federal criminal code to include the killing or attempted killing of a local or state law enforcement officer or first responder as an aggravating factor in Federal death penalty determinations.  - H.R. 1428, the American Law Enforcement Heroes Act of 2017; incentivizes state and local government to hire American veterans and new law enforcement officers. Specifically, the bill amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to authorize COPS Hiring program grantees to use grant funds to hire veterans as career law enforcement officers;  - H.R. 510, the Rapid DNA Act of 2017; directs the FBI to issue standards and procedures for the use of certain automated processes to analyze DNA samples;  - H.R. 1616, the Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017; authorizes the National Computer Forensics Institute, which is located in Hoover, Alabama. This center is operated by the U.S. Secret Service and trains state and local law enforcement, prosecutors, and judges from all over the nation in handling digital evidence. It has trained more than 6,250 local officials from all 50 states and three U.S. Territories.  -H.R. 1892, the Honoring Hometown Heroes Act; authorizes the governors of a state or territory to proclaim that the United States flag shall be flown at half-staff in the event that a public safety officer dies while serving in the line of duty.   -H.R. 1039, the Probation Officer Protection Act of 2017; authorizes a probation officer to arrest a person, without warrant, if there is probable cause to believe the person forcibly assaulted or obstructed a probation officer while performing their official duties.   For more information, visit the House Judiciary Committee.

#MemorialDay is a time to remember those who have lost their lives fighting for this great country and to reflect on their noble, selfless sacrifice. Amid all the fun and relaxation that can come with a holiday weekend, I hope you and your family will take time to remember the meaning of Memorial Day and to honor the brave Americans who died so that we may be free.   At today's Memorial Day observances at Arlington National Cemetery, General Joseph Dunford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, offered meaningful remarks about that sacrifice and what we can do to honor it from a Marine's perspective. Please take a moment to read what he said and share it with friends and family around you. There's also a video clip you can watch: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=ImBYDqdgu8w   General Dunford:  "Mr. President, Mr. Vice President, Secretary Mattis and, most importantly, Gold Star Families, it is an honor to join you this morning in remembrance and reflection. Since the founding of our republic, more than 42 million Americans have stepped forward to serve their country in uniform. Their story is one of selflessness, it's one of courage, and it's one of sheer commitment. But their story is also one of extraordinary sacrifice. More than one million Americans who have answered the last full measure of their devotion so their fellow citizens could live in freedom and raise their children in peace.   "Today we honor the fallen from battlefields that served as weigh points in our history: from Saratoga to Gettysburg, And Bellau Wood to Midway, from Chosin to la Drang, and from Korengal Valley to Fallujah, today we reflect on the enormity of the sacrifice. We reflect on the hopes and the dreams never realized.   "Today we also reflect on the sacrifice of the families left behind: the anguish of parents, spouses, siblings and friends; the sadness of children growing up without their fathers or mothers. And we know that for the families, every day is memorial day.   "But today we also reflect on what's most important about the men and women we honor. We reflect on how they lived. They were people who stood for something larger than themselves. They were people who embodied the most important values and tradition traditions of our nation. They were people that understood that what we have in our country is worth fighting for. And though they were taken from us prematurely, they were people that touched our lives, they were people who made a difference.   "Today if we truly want to honor the fallen from all our conflicts, we'll do something more than mark their graves with flags and flowers. We'll do something more than delivering remarks and reflect for just a few moments. If we truly want to give meaning to the sacrifice of those who have given all on our behalf, each of us will leave here today determined to find in some small way a method of serving our nation in our communities in their honor. If we do that, then I would offer that those of us who were taken from us prematurely will be able to look down and know that we truly do remember them.   "Ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of soldiers, sailors, airmen and coast guardsmen still in uniform, thank you for remembering."
